snippet: United Nations diplomats emphasized that the government had yet to make good on its pledges under the plan to withdraw troops and heavy weapons from major cities.
abstract: Fragile cease-fire negotiated by United Nations special envoy Kofi Annan prevails in most of Syria, the first vaguely optimistic signal in months in the nation's bloody antigovernment uprising, but some deadly clashes are reported and activists say areas that had been riven by violence remain under virtual martial law.

byline.original: By HALA DROUBI and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Hala Droubi reported from Beirut, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Neil MacFarquhar from Beirut, Alan Cowell from London, Steven Lee Myers from Washington, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.

lead_paragraph: United Nations diplomats emphasized that the government had yet to make good on its pledges under the plan to withdraw troops and heavy weapons from major cities.

headline.seo: A Tenuous Cease-Fire Prevails in Most of Syria
headline.main: Cease-Fire Is Prevailing Across Most of Syria
headline.print_headline: Cease-Fire Is Prevailing Across Most Of Syria
